abstract.text: A component that manages character movement.

inlineContent.text: To use a character controller, add a
to your entity to make it a character entity.
Use
to move your character and respond to collisions, or
to place your character instantaneously in 3D space.
and
are incompatible with
, and RealityKit deactivates them if you add them to the same entity.
Character entities are capsular, and you can specify their height and radius in the component’s initializer.
A character’s capsule shape aligns with its
so that the top and bottom of the capsule pass through that direction vector.
Although characters don’t have a
, they can still interact with colliders.
The collision handler in
allows you to respond to collisions with solid colliders in your scene.

code: entity.moveCharacter(by: velocity * deltaTime, deltaTime: deltaTime, relativeTo: nil) {

inlineContent.text: To handle collisions with colliders that have a
of
, subscribe to the
event for your
This event doesn’t occur for solid collisions with your character, but RealityKit invokes it when your character enters a trigger.
This is useful for collecting coins, claiming checkpoints, activating enemy behavior when your character enters an area, and many other interactions within games.
A common use case for
is to control a character in a video game.
Video games have update loops where characters and game logic update once each frame, allowing them to respond to player input in real time.
works well in such a setup.
To move your character in response to player input, subscribe to
on
for your scene.
The event object contains information like the time delta since the last update, and you can treat this callback as the update loop for your game.
You can also use
to run code for each frame, but avoid using it to control physics-based motion in your scene.
Read the values from
to accumulate forces (such as gravity) and to check whether the character is on the ground.
RealityKit calculates
and
only after you call
, so it’s a good idea to call this function at each update.

code: // RealityKit automatically adds `CharacterControllerStateComponent` after moving the character for the first time.
// Gravity is a force, so you need to accumulate it for each frame.
// Set the character's velocity directly to launch it in the air when the player jumps.
playerEntity.moveCharacter(by: velocity * deltaTime, deltaTime: deltaTime, relativeTo: nil) {

abstract.text: Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
A component that manages character movement.
A container that holds collision state for the character controller.
An option set that specifies which parts of the character capsule have collided with other objects.
The character’s collision filter.
The capsule height value RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The capsule default radius RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The skin width value RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The slope limit value RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The step limit value RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The default up vector RealityKit applies when you use the default initializer.
The capsule height.
Creates a character controller component using default values.
Creates a character controller component using specified values.
The capsule radius.
An added tolerance around the character capsule.
The slope limit expressed as a limit angle in radians.
The maximum obstacle height that the controller can move over.
The y-axis direction relative to the physics origin.
A component that represents the state of a character controller.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the character controller is on the ground.
The linear speed relative to the origin in physics space.
A component that gives an entity the ability to collide with other entities
that also have collision components.
A trigger collision object.
The collision mode.
An event raised when two objects collide.
A representation of a geometry or a behavior that you apply to an entity.
Moves the character along a specified vector over a period of time.
Moves the character instantly to a new position.
A set of animatable transform values for joints that collectively represent
a single skeletal pose.
A component that defines an entity’s behavior in physics body simulations.
The event raised before the simulation advances to the current frame.
A view that contains RealityKit content.
The content of a visionOS reality view.
An event invoked once per frame interval that you can use to execute
custom logic for each frame.
